testimony.name: Salinas Miranda
key_points: The proposal does not include low income and very low income housing
City of Yes primarily benefits private developers
It will not solve the homeless crisis
Constituents should be included in community decision-making processes
Concerns about private developers abusing power (e.g., Related Companies in Chelsea)
Existing buildings only need maintenance and repairs, not demolition
Opposes changing zoning to increase building heights and population density
Concerned about the impact on elderly, sick, disabled, and mental well-being of tenants
Calls for protecting the city from overdevelopment
Opposes rezoning and demolition in Chelsea
Suggests implementing rent caps for all housing
Calls for a comprehensive rent control plan from the mayor

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: High re high restriction should always exist.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote suggests that the speaker is against relaxing height restrictions, which is related to the Transit-Oriented Development element of the proposal. The City of Yes plan aims to allow 3- to 5-story apartment buildings near transit, which would involve changing height restrictions in some areas.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: They want to change the zoning to double the height and increase the population and change the aesthetics of our tranquil and cozy community.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly addresses the issue of changing zoning to allow for taller buildings and increased population density, which is a key aspect of the Transit-Oriented Development element of the City of Yes proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Keep our height limit and no rezoning of 14 Ellie in Chelsea.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This statement explicitly opposes changes to height limits and rezoning, which are central to the Transit-Oriented Development aspect of the City of Yes proposal. The speaker is advocating for maintaining current height restrictions, which goes against the proposal's aim to allow taller buildings near transit.
